meta.title: Digital Health Transformation & Assurance — Wisdom → Super-Concepts → Systems → Governance → Operations → Improvement → Cases
meta.subtitle: A dense lattice of interconnections from patient-safety-first wisdom to the practical mechanics of regulated digital health (AI, data, governance, evidence, investor readiness) and real-world failure modes.
meta.searchPlaceholder: patient safety, clinical evidence, integrated governance, DCB0129, DCB0160, DTAC, medical device regulation, SaMD, QMS, ISO 13485, ISO 14971, post-market surveillance, data quality, dataset access, bias, model validation, human factors, cybersecurity, pitch deck, financial model, milestones, product-market fit, unmet need, defensibility…
meta.userContextLabel: Your digital health / pharma transformation context (optional)
meta.userContextPlaceholder: e.g., pharma R&D team piloting AI triage; NHS procurement target; limited dataset access; runway pressure; need regulatory roadmap + evidence + investor deck…
meta.promptTemplate:
You are an expert digital health assurance lead with deep experience in clinical safety, regulation, evidence generation, and digital transformation.

Write a realistic narrative case study that traces from upstream management wisdom down to operational decisions.
Your goal: show how to build (or rescue) a digital health / AI product so it is safe, clinically effective, regulatory-ready, commercially aligned, and investable.

User context (if provided):
{{USER_CONTEXT}}

Selected concepts:
{{SELECTED_TITLES}}

Details:
{{SELECTED_DETAILS}}

Trace paths:
{{TRACE_SUMMARY}}

Critical instruction:
- Anchor the story around at least ONE selected CASE (orange) or RISK/PATHOLOGY (red).
- If none is selected, propose 3 candidate cases from the map and invite the user to choose one.
- Invite the user to specify (or invent) a closely related case: setting (NHS/private/pharma), user group, data source, intended claims, deployment context, and what went wrong/right.

Deliver:
- Scenario (actors, setting, patient/user group, intended outcome, constraints)
- What problem is being solved + evidence of unmet need
- Team composition + co-creation plan (patients/clinicians)
- Integrated governance plan (clinical, IG, HR credentialing, corporate, financial)
- Regulatory roadmap aligned to commercial strategy (as an enabler)
- Data + compute plan (access, quality, bias, validation)
- Evidence plan (safety first, then ‘does it work’)
- Investor readiness plan (deck story + financial model + milestone spend)
- Failure modes + prevention (what to do early to avoid costly rework)
- 2 safe-to-fail experiments and leading indicators

levels.title: Professional wisdom
levels.hint: Judgement-in-context: patient safety, integrity, humility about unknown unknowns, and disciplined foundations.

levels.title: Super-concepts
levels.hint: Shaping ideas: trust, legitimacy, value, incentives, evidence, and execution under runway pressure.

levels.title: Systems concepts
levels.hint: How projects behave: feedback loops, bottlenecks (data, regulation), drift, interfaces, and socio-technical coupling.

levels.title: Governance & programme architecture
levels.hint: Integrated governance: clinical safety, information governance, HR credentialing, corporate/financial governance, regulatory strategy.

levels.title: Operational delivery mechanisms
levels.hint: Co-creation, data pipelines, model development/validation, documentation, clinical evaluation, deployment and monitoring.

levels.title: Quality, performance & improvement
levels.hint: Assurance and scaling: evidence loops, audits, KPIs, milestone planning, investor readiness, continuous improvement.

levels.title: Cases, challenges & pathologies
levels.hint: Concrete scenarios and common failure modes for tracing back to root causes and governance gaps.

nodes.label: Patient safety first (non-negotiable)
nodes.summary: Start with safety; if it isn’t safe, you won’t sustain product–market fit.
nodes.bodyHtml: Make safety the first design constraint. Safety precedes growth: unsafe products trigger harm, enforcement, and loss of trust—destroying viability.

nodes.label: Build foundations, not sandcastles
nodes.summary: Integrated governance early enables speed later (less haste, more speed).
nodes.bodyHtml: Early investment in governance, evidence, and data discipline prevents expensive rework and accelerates scale.

nodes.label: Co-creation with users (humility + respect)
nodes.summary: Include patients/clinicians continuously; don’t treat feedback as a one-off.
nodes.bodyHtml: Digital health succeeds when end users shape requirements, workflows, and risk controls throughout development and deployment.

nodes.label: Regulation as an enabler
nodes.summary: Regulation isn’t a block; done well it unlocks trust and revenue streams.
nodes.bodyHtml: Regulatory readiness can be a competitive advantage: it reduces buyer risk (e.g., NHS), supports claims, and accelerates partnerships.

nodes.label: Evidence over excitement
nodes.summary: Generate evidence early that it’s safe and that it works.
nodes.bodyHtml: Innovation without clinical evidence and safety rationale becomes fragile: it stalls at procurement, regulatory gates, and trust checks.

nodes.label: Audience empathy (simple story, right detail)
nodes.summary: Pitch and communicate for the audience: investors want clarity and numbers.
nodes.bodyHtml: Healthcare is complex. Translate complexity into a clear narrative: one sentence, problem–solution, evidence, market, business model, milestones.

nodes.label: Execution at the right speed
nodes.summary: Avoid rushing; build a high-performing team that can deliver reliably.
nodes.bodyHtml: Success correlates with disciplined execution: roadmap clarity, role clarity, and team culture that manages cross-functional tension.

nodes.label: Trust & legitimacy
nodes.summary: Clinical credibility, transparency, and governance build user and buyer confidence.
nodes.bodyHtml: Trust is a system property produced by safety, evidence, communication, and consistent governance.

nodes.label: Unmet need & problem–solution fit
nodes.summary: Start by validating the problem and the genuine need before building.
nodes.bodyHtml: Market assessment prevents building impressive technology that doesn’t solve a high-value problem.

nodes.label: Value proposition (clinical + economic)
nodes.summary: Define measurable value for patients, clinicians, and payers.
nodes.bodyHtml: Healthcare adoption requires value across stakeholders: outcomes, workload, risk reduction, and cost/efficiency.

nodes.label: Stakeholder alignment (patients, clinicians, payers, regulators)
nodes.summary: Align incentives and expectations across stakeholders to avoid adoption failure.
nodes.bodyHtml: Different stakeholders prize different evidence. Align messaging, evidence, and governance to each.

nodes.label: Regulatory roadmap aligned to commercial strategy
nodes.summary: Define claims, target buyers, and standards early to avoid rework.
nodes.bodyHtml: Intended use and claims define evidence and compliance needs; these must be aligned to go-to-market.

nodes.label: USP & defensibility
nodes.summary: Know competitors; build defensibility (data access, workflow lock-in, IP, partnerships).
nodes.bodyHtml: Defensibility prevents competitors taking the market while you fix governance or evidence gaps.

nodes.label: Investor readiness (story + numbers)
nodes.summary: Pitch deck + financial model + milestone plan; communicate complex science simply.
nodes.bodyHtml: Investor readiness is the ability to explain the business clearly, show progress logic, and justify use of funds to milestones.

nodes.label: Runway economics (time is cost)
nodes.summary: Data access delays and regulatory rework burn runway; plan early.
nodes.bodyHtml: Delays are expensive. Plan for data acquisition, evidence generation, and compliance work as first-class roadmap items.

nodes.label: Right team (diverse skills + culture)
nodes.summary: Clinicians, data science, product, engineering, marketing, governance; build a shared culture.
nodes.bodyHtml: Digital health needs multidisciplinary skills. Success correlates strongly with team completeness and high-performance collaboration.

nodes.label: Safety → then effectiveness (evidence logic)
nodes.summary: First: is it safe? Second: does it work? Both need evidence.
nodes.bodyHtml: Evidence planning should match risks, claims, and deployment context; safety is a gate, not a feature.

nodes.label: Integrated governance breadth
nodes.summary: Clinical governance plus HR credentialing, IG, corporate, and financial governance.
nodes.bodyHtml: Digital health failures often come from neglected governance domains: contracting, access controls, credentialing, escalation routes, or financial oversight.

nodes.label: Communication simplicity (reading age 7–11 when needed)
nodes.summary: Cut content; use visuals; tell a clear story; tailor to audience.
nodes.bodyHtml: Sector-agnostic investors and busy stakeholders need clarity, structure, and decisive framing—not dense technical exposition.

nodes.label: Unknown unknowns & discovery risk
nodes.summary: Early projects hide constraints; multidisciplinary teams reduce blind spots.
nodes.bodyHtml: Digital health projects often discover data access, regulatory scope, and workflow constraints late unless explored early.

nodes.label: Feedback loops (evidence + safety signals)
nodes.summary: Collect signals from use, incidents, outcomes; feed back into design and governance.
nodes.bodyHtml: Clinical evidence, post-market monitoring, and user feedback should continuously reshape product, processes, and claims.

nodes.label: Bottlenecks: data access & permissions
nodes.summary: Data availability is often the blocker; delays consume runway.
nodes.bodyHtml: Data access depends on legal basis, agreements, technical extraction, and governance. Plan lead times and alternatives.

nodes.label: Data quality, representativeness & bias
nodes.summary: AI is only as good as its data; bias and missingness create safety risk.
nodes.bodyHtml: Quality includes correctness, completeness, timeliness, and representativeness across user groups.

nodes.label: Socio-technical fit (workflow + humans + tech)
nodes.summary: Safety and effectiveness depend on workflow integration and human factors.
nodes.bodyHtml: Even accurate models can fail if deployed into the wrong workflow, with wrong incentives, or poor usability.

nodes.label: Interfaces & handoffs
nodes.summary: Failures cluster at boundaries: referrals, data transfers, reporting, escalation.
nodes.bodyHtml: Most preventable harm and compliance failures occur at interfaces between teams, systems, and organisations.

nodes.label: Drift & technical debt
nodes.summary: Quality degrades unless actively maintained; documentation and controls drift out of date.
nodes.bodyHtml: Model performance, data pipelines, and governance documents degrade over time; proactive monitoring and change control are required.

nodes.label: Incentives & Goodhart’s law
nodes.summary: Metrics distort behaviour; speed-only KPIs can create unsafe shortcuts.
nodes.bodyHtml: Choose measures that promote safe outcomes and learning, not gaming or rushed releases.

nodes.label: Stage gates & decision points
nodes.summary: Define go/no-go gates: safety, evidence, regulation, deployment readiness, funding milestones.
nodes.bodyHtml: Stage gates prevent ‘build first, govern later’ failure modes and help explain progress to investors and buyers.

nodes.label: Integrated governance (clinical + IG + HR + corporate + financial)
nodes.summary: A joined-up governance model supporting safe scaling.
nodes.bodyHtml: Integrated governance spans clinical safety, information governance, credentialing, corporate oversight, finance, and risk management.

nodes.label: Clinical governance
nodes.summary: Clinical safety case, escalation routes, supervision, incident management, and evidence oversight.
nodes.bodyHtml: Ensures safe clinical practice, appropriate claims, and oversight of clinical evaluation and deployment.

nodes.label: Information governance (privacy, security, access)
nodes.summary: Data protection, access control, secure processing, retention, breach response.
nodes.bodyHtml: Information governance turns trust principles into operational controls around sensitive health data.

nodes.label: HR governance: credentialing & competence
nodes.summary: Credential clinicians, define roles, supervision, and competence assurance.
nodes.bodyHtml: Credentialing and competence planning prevent unsafe practice and support scalable service delivery.

nodes.label: Corporate governance (accountability + oversight)
nodes.summary: Board/leadership oversight of risk, quality, strategy alignment, and compliance posture.
nodes.bodyHtml: Clear accountability prevents late surprises and ensures risk owners exist for safety, evidence, and compliance.

nodes.label: Financial governance (spend-to-milestone discipline)
nodes.summary: Align spending to milestones; avoid ‘woolly’ progress narratives.
nodes.bodyHtml: Financial governance links runway to execution: what will be built, evidenced, and certified by the next funding gate.

nodes.label: Clinical risk management standard (DCB0129)
nodes.summary: Clinical risk management for health IT (supplier-focused in NHS context).
nodes.bodyHtml: Used to structure clinical risk management and evidence of safety controls for digital health systems.

nodes.label: Clinical risk management standard (DCB0160)
nodes.summary: Clinical risk management for health IT (deployment/organisation-focused in NHS context).
nodes.bodyHtml: Complements supplier-side obligations by specifying deployment-side safety governance and responsibilities.

nodes.label: NHS DTAC (Digital Technology Assessment Criteria)
nodes.summary: Procurement expectations: clinical safety, data protection, security, interoperability, usability, etc.
nodes.bodyHtml: DTAC readiness reduces procurement friction and demonstrates baseline assurance.

nodes.label: Medical device / SaMD regulatory pathway
nodes.summary: Determine if the product is a medical device; align claims, evidence, QMS, and post-market obligations.
nodes.bodyHtml: Regulatory classification is driven by intended use and claims. Get this right early to avoid rework.

nodes.label: Team composition & roles
nodes.summary: Clinicians, data science, product, engineering, marketing, governance; clarify responsibilities.
nodes.bodyHtml: Key hires often include a data scientist and (for tech businesses) a CTO; add clinical safety and governance leadership early.

nodes.label: Co-creation practices (focus groups, pilots, continuous feedback)
nodes.summary: Engage patients and clinicians repeatedly through discovery, build, and rollout.
nodes.bodyHtml: Use structured sessions and ongoing engagement to prevent building the wrong workflow or missing safety-critical needs.

nodes.label: Problem definition & market assessment
nodes.summary: Define the problem, validate unmet need, and map the competitive landscape.
nodes.bodyHtml: Translate excitement into a clear problem statement and evidence of need; include competitor and buyer analysis.

nodes.label: Regulatory roadmap execution
nodes.summary: Identify applicable standards, evidence needs, documentation, and timelines early.
nodes.bodyHtml: Plan compliance work as part of product development, not as a late-stage scramble.

nodes.label: Data strategy (access, format, governance)
nodes.summary: Specify data needs, acquisition plan, legal basis, and lead times.
nodes.bodyHtml: Data acquisition is often the critical path; align agreements, pipelines, and governance early.

nodes.label: Data quality management
nodes.summary: Define quality metrics; validate completeness, correctness, and representativeness.
nodes.bodyHtml: Data quality is a safety issue for AI products; document checks, monitoring, and remediation.

nodes.label: Compute & MLOps infrastructure
nodes.summary: Secure compute, reproducibility, deployment controls, monitoring, and rollback.
nodes.bodyHtml: Infrastructure choices affect privacy, auditability, reliability, and the ability to scale safely.

nodes.label: Model development & validation
nodes.summary: Define intended use; validate performance and safety across subgroups; document limitations.
nodes.bodyHtml: Validation must match deployment context and claims; include bias and robustness checks.

nodes.label: Clinical evaluation & evidence generation
nodes.summary: Generate evidence for safety and effectiveness; align to claims and user workflows.
nodes.bodyHtml: Evidence can include usability/human factors, observational studies, and controlled evaluations depending on risk and claims.

nodes.label: Incident reporting & escalation pathways
nodes.summary: Define thresholds, responsibilities, and rapid response mechanisms.
nodes.bodyHtml: Plan what happens when harm, near-miss, data breach, or model drift occurs; document actions and learning loops.

nodes.label: Documentation & safety case
nodes.summary: Maintain decision logs, risk assessments, clinical safety case, and evidence files.
nodes.bodyHtml: Documentation makes governance real: it supports audits, procurement, and safe scaling across environments.

nodes.label: Pitch deck construction (investor-friendly)
nodes.summary: One sentence; problem, solution, market, competition, evidence, traction, plan, numbers.
nodes.bodyHtml: The deck’s job is to get the meeting. Keep it concise and tailored to the audience.

nodes.label: Financial modeling (assumptions → data)
nodes.summary: Make assumptions explicit; replace with data over time; link costs to milestones and go-to-market.
nodes.bodyHtml: Financial models force clarity on hiring, timelines, CAC, unit economics, and milestone-based funding needs.

nodes.label: KPIs (leading + lagging)
nodes.summary: Measure safety, evidence progress, data quality, delivery throughput, and learning loops (not just speed).
nodes.bodyHtml: Use metrics to learn, not punish: safety incidents, drift, evidence milestones, data quality indicators, and user outcomes.

nodes.label: Audit & assurance cadence
nodes.summary: Regularly test governance, documentation, security, and clinical safety controls in practice.
nodes.bodyHtml: Audit finds drift and interface failures early; it supports readiness for procurement and regulatory scrutiny.

nodes.label: Learning loops & continuous improvement
nodes.summary: Turn feedback, incidents, evidence, and complaints into system changes and re-checks.
nodes.bodyHtml: Continuous improvement closes the loop: evidence updates governance; governance reshapes operations; operations generate new evidence.

nodes.label: Milestone-based funding plan
nodes.summary: Define what the money buys and what milestone it unlocks next.
nodes.bodyHtml: Milestones connect roadmap to capital. Clear milestones make the next round easier and reduce narrative ambiguity.

nodes.label: Governance reviews (integrated)
nodes.summary: Periodic reviews across clinical, IG, HR, corporate, and finance to keep alignment intact.
nodes.bodyHtml: Integrated review prevents local optimisation and ensures regulation, evidence, and commercial strategy remain aligned.

nodes.label: Pathology: Regulation engaged too late
nodes.summary: Late compliance work causes rework, delays, cost blowouts, and risk exposure.
nodes.bodyHtml: Teams move fast, skip early regulatory thinking, then discover they must redo evidence, documentation, or even product claims.

nodes.label: Challenge: Data unavailable or delayed
nodes.summary: Launch stalls because data access, permissions, or formats were underestimated.
nodes.bodyHtml: Data acquisition takes time (agreements, extraction, cleaning). Delays burn runway and compress safety/evidence work.

nodes.label: Pathology: AI bias leads to unsafe recommendations
nodes.summary: Non-representative data and weak validation create differential harm across groups.
nodes.bodyHtml: Bias is a clinical safety risk: validate across subgroups and monitor drift post-deployment.

nodes.label: Challenge: Missing key roles (CTO/data science/clinical safety)
nodes.summary: Blind spots emerge; delivery quality and safety governance degrade.
nodes.bodyHtml: Digital health requires diverse skills. Gaps lead to poor data strategy, weak evidence, or fragile infrastructure.

nodes.label: Pathology: Moving too fast (foundation debt)
nodes.summary: Rushing creates governance and quality debt that explodes later.
nodes.bodyHtml: Short-term speed causes long-term delays: rework, incidents, procurement failure, and eroded trust.

nodes.label: Pathology: Pitch deck too dense to land
nodes.summary: Too much content; weak story; doesn’t match investor audience; fails to secure meetings.
nodes.bodyHtml: Founders often over-explain science. Investors need a simple narrative and credible numbers tied to milestones.

nodes.label: Challenge: Competitor captures market during rework
nodes.summary: While you fix compliance/evidence issues, competitors ship and win share.
nodes.bodyHtml: Late regulatory fixes are not just costly—they are strategic delays that can be fatal in a fast-moving market.

nodes.label: Case: NHS pilot blocked by DTAC and clinical safety gaps
nodes.summary: Product works in demo but fails procurement due to missing DTAC artefacts and clinical safety case.
nodes.bodyHtml: Root cause: regulatory roadmap not defined early; documentation and IG controls not built into development.

nodes.label: Case: Model performance drifts after deployment
nodes.summary: Clinical workflow or population changes; model accuracy drops; incidents rise.
nodes.bodyHtml: Requires MLOps monitoring, incident pathways, and governance triggers for retraining, rollback, or claim changes.

nodes.label: Case: Launch delayed six months waiting for data agreements
nodes.summary: Underestimated permissions, contracts, extraction complexity; runway pressure forces risky shortcuts.
nodes.bodyHtml: Fix with early data strategy, alternative datasets, staged evidence plan, and aligned funding milestones.

nodes.label: Case: Great product, average deck—funding stalls
nodes.summary: Science-heavy deck fails to get meetings; needs story discipline and numbers tied to milestones.
nodes.bodyHtml: Rewrite around one-sentence explanation, evidence, market, competition, and milestone-based spend plan.

nodes.label: Case: Medical device classification discovered late
nodes.summary: Claims trigger SaMD pathway; evidence and QMS need redesign; timeline slips.
nodes.bodyHtml: Prevention: define intended use and claims early; map standards and evidence to commercial strategy from day one.
